instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.P3V42_G3H: What is P3V42_G3H? P3V42_G3H is a typo of PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PBUS_G3H: What is PBUS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PBUS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message:
Board had corrosion on <RESISTOR>R6128</RESISTOR> that got repaired fine.

<SIGNAL>M_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>M_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>CH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>M_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>M_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>
AND
<SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>] [p:<CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>:1
<SIGNAL>P5V_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>P3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>

All above rails are present and correct, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds

Already reballed SMC and tried clean BIOS and checked pages 57-58 but no luck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message:
Please, take your time when post and write signal names correctly.
Forget copy/paste, if you cannot do it in decent mode.
Do you consider lost time to do that properly???

Remember, no need to measure same power rail in different points (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_X</SIGNAL>).

I'm wondering how do you get steady <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> when <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is pulsing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message:
Will do, no problem.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0V, I measured a different component.

Here is the list again:

<SIGNAL>PBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>PVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>P5V_S5</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>P3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL> pulses too
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses too
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> Missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Present"
I hope is 12.5V and not 12.3V.

So no pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and/or other big coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Present 8.59V this is a MBA

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  pulses
L7430, L7630, L7310/20 VCORE all pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message: Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
threads.message:
Check ALL SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Be sure J6100 is clean; you may need to remove it.
Also try known good working BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses every 3-4 seconds
